Banach-Alaoglu

Let H={z∈C∣Im⁡z>0}\H = \set{z \in \C \mid \Im{z} > 0}H={z∈C∣Imz>0} be the upper-half plane. Let f ⁣:H→H\func{f}{\H}{\H}f:H→H be a holomorphic function obeying

lim⁡y→∞yf(iy)=iand∣f(z)∣≤1Im⁡zfor all z∈H.\lim_{y\to\infty} yf\p{iy} = i \quad\text{and}\quad \abs{f\p{z}} \leq \frac{1}{\Im{z}} \quad\text{for all } z \in \H.y→∞lim​yf(iy)=iand∣f(z)∣≤Imz1​for all z∈H.

  1. For ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, write gε(x)=1πIm⁡f(x+iε)g_\epsilon\p{x} = \frac{1}{\pi} \Im{f\p{x + i\epsilon}}gε​(x)=π1​Imf(x+iε). Show that

    f(z+iε)=∫Rgε(x)x−z dx.f\p{z + i\epsilon} = \int_\R \frac{g_\epsilon\p{x}}{x - z} \,\diff{x}.f(z+iε)=∫R​x−zgε​(x)​dx.

  2. Show that there exists a Borel probability measure μ\muμ on R\RR such that

    f(z)=∫Rdμ(x)x−z.f\p{z} = \int_\R \frac{\diff\mu\p{x}}{x - z}.f(z)=∫R​x−zdμ(x)​.
Solution.

  1. We have the Schwarz integral formula for the upper-half plane:

    f(z)=1πi∫RRe⁡f(x)x−z dx+Cf\p{z} = \frac{1}{\pi i} \int_\R \frac{\Re{f\p{x}}}{x - z} \,\diff{x} + Cf(z)=πi1​∫R​x−zRef(x)​dx+C

    for z∈Hz \in \Hz∈H and some real constant CCC. Replacing fff with −if-if−if, we see

    −if(z)=1πi∫RIm⁡f(x)x−z dx+C  ⟹  f(z+iε)=1π∫RIm⁡f(x+iε)x−z dx+iC.-if\p{z} = \frac{1}{\pi i} \int_\R \frac{\Im{f\p{x}}}{x - z} \,\diff{x} + C \implies f\p{z + i\epsilon} = \frac{1}{\pi} \int_\R \frac{\Im{f\p{x + i\epsilon}}}{x - z} \,\diff{x} + iC.−if(z)=πi1​∫R​x−zImf(x)​dx+C⟹f(z+iε)=π1​∫R​x−zImf(x+iε)​dx+iC.

    We will show in (2) that C=0C = 0C=0.

  2. The map h↦∫Rhgε dxh \mapsto \int_\R hg_\epsilon \,\diff{x}h↦∫R​hgε​dx defines a linear function on C0(R)C_0\p{\R}C0​(R), i.e., the closure of compactly supported continuous functions on R\RR. Thus, we may view {gε}ε⊆(C0(R))∗\set{g_\epsilon}_\epsilon \subseteq \p{C_0\p{\R}}^*{gε​}ε​⊆(C0​(R))∗, the space of Radon measures. We wish to apply Banach-Alaoglu, so we need to show that ∥gε∥(C0(R))∗\norm{g_\epsilon}_{\p{C_0\p{\R}}^*}∥gε​∥(C0​(R))∗​ is uniformly bounded.

    Write z=x+iyz = x + iyz=x+iy. For ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, consider the contour γ\gammaγ, which is an upper semicircle centered at x+iεx + i\epsilonx+iε of radius RRR. Notice that if 0<ε<y<R0 < \epsilon < y < R0<ε<y<R, then zzz is in the interior of γ\gammaγ and z‾+2iε\conj{z} + 2i\epsilonz+2iε is outside. Then by the Cauchy integral formula,

    f(z)=12πi∫γ(1ζ−z−1ζ−z‾−2iε)f(ζ) dζ=1π∫γy−ε(ζ−z)(ζ−z‾−2iε)f(ζ) dζ=1π∫−RRy−εt2+(y−ε)2f(x+iε+t) dt+iπ∫0πy−εR2e2iθ+(y−ε)2f(x+iε+Reiθ)Reiθ dθ.\begin{aligned} f\p{z} &= \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_\gamma \p{\frac{1}{\zeta - z} - \frac{1}{\zeta - \conj{z} - 2i\epsilon}} f\p{\zeta} \,\diff\zeta \\ &= \frac{1}{\pi} \int_\gamma \frac{y - \epsilon}{\p{\zeta - z}\p{\zeta - \conj{z} - 2i\epsilon}} f\p{\zeta} \,\diff\zeta \\ &= \frac{1}{\pi} \int_{-R}^R \frac{y - \epsilon}{t^2 + \p{y - \epsilon}^2} f\p{x + i\epsilon + t} \,\diff{t} + \frac{i}{\pi} \int_0^\pi \frac{y - \epsilon}{R^2e^{2i\theta} + \p{y - \epsilon}^2} f\p{x + i\epsilon + Re^{i\theta}} Re^{i\theta} \,\diff\theta. \end{aligned}f(z)​=2πi1​∫γ​(ζ−z1​−ζ−z−2iε1​)f(ζ)dζ=π1​∫γ​(ζ−z)(ζ−z−2iε)y−ε​f(ζ)dζ=π1​∫−RR​t2+(y−ε)2y−ε​f(x+iε+t)dt+πi​∫0π​R2e2iθ+(y−ε)2y−ε​f(x+iε+Reiθ)Reiθdθ.​

    In the second integral, ∣f(x+iε+Reiθ)∣≤1ε+Rsin⁡θ\abs{f\p{x + i\epsilon + Re^{i\theta}}} \leq \frac{1}{\epsilon + R\sin\theta}∣∣​f(x+iε+Reiθ)∣∣​≤ε+Rsinθ1​, and so the integrand tends to 000 as R→∞R \to \inftyR→∞. Thus, by dominated convergence, we may send R→∞R \to \inftyR→∞ to get

    f(z)=1π∫Ry−ε(t−x)2+(y−ε)2f(t+iε) dtf\p{z} = \frac{1}{\pi} \int_\R \frac{y - \epsilon}{\p{t - x}^2 + \p{y - \epsilon}^2} f\p{t + i\epsilon} \,\diff{t}f(z)=π1​∫R​(t−x)2+(y−ε)2y−ε​f(t+iε)dt

    via a translation change of variables. Taking imaginary parts and multiplying both sides by yyy, we see

    ∫Ry−ε(t−x)2+(y−ε)2gε(t) dt=Im⁡f(z)≤1Im⁡z  ⟹  ∫Ry(y−ε)(t−x)2+(y−ε)2gε(t) dt≤1.\begin{gathered} \int_\R \frac{y - \epsilon}{\p{t - x}^2 + \p{y - \epsilon}^2} g_\epsilon\p{t} \,\diff{t} = \Im{f\p{z}} \leq \frac{1}{\Im{z}} \\ \implies \int_\R \frac{y\p{y - \epsilon}}{\p{t - x}^2 + \p{y - \epsilon}^2} g_\epsilon\p{t} \,\diff{t} \leq 1. \end{gathered}∫R​(t−x)2+(y−ε)2y−ε​gε​(t)dt=Imf(z)≤Imz1​⟹∫R​(t−x)2+(y−ε)2y(y−ε)​gε​(t)dt≤1.​

    Sending y→∞y \to \inftyy→∞ and applying dominated convergence, we see ∫Rgε(t) dt≤1\int_\R g_\epsilon\p{t} \,\diff{t} \leq 1∫R​gε​(t)dt≤1. Thus, {gε}ε\set{g_\epsilon}_\epsilon{gε​}ε​ is uniformly bounded, so by Banach-Alaoglu and taking ε=1n\epsilon = \frac{1}{n}ε=n1​, we get a subsequence gnkg_{n_k}gnk​​ which converges weakly to a Radon measure μ\muμ. In particular, 1x−z∈C0(R)\frac{1}{x - z} \in C_0\p{\R}x−z1​∈C0​(R), so by weak convergence,

    ∫Rgnk(x)x−z dx→k→∞∫Rdμ(x)x−z,\int_\R \frac{g_{n_k}\p{x}}{x - z} \,\diff{x} \xrightarrow{k\to\infty} \int_\R \frac{\diff\mu\p{x}}{x - z},∫R​x−zgnk​​(x)​dxk→∞​∫R​x−zdμ(x)​,

    which gives the representation

    f(z)=∫Rdμ(x)x−z+iC.f\p{z} = \int_\R \frac{\diff\mu\p{x}}{x - z} + iC.f(z)=∫R​x−zdμ(x)​+iC.

    Notice that if z=iyz = iyz=iy, then ∣yx−iy∣=yx2+y2\abs{\frac{y}{x - iy}} = \frac{y}{\sqrt{x^2 + y^2}}∣∣​x−iyy​∣∣​=x2+y2​y​ is bounded. Since μ\muμ is a finite measure, we see that 1x−z∈L1(R,μ)\frac{1}{x - z} \in L^1\p{\R, \mu}x−z1​∈L1(R,μ), is dominated by 111, so by dominated convergence,

    lim⁡n→∞∫Ryx−iy dμ(x)=−1iμ(R)=iμ(R).\lim_{n\to\infty} \int_\R \frac{y}{x - iy} \,\diff\mu\p{x} = -\frac{1}{i} \mu\p{\R} = i\mu\p{\R}.n→∞lim​∫R​x−iyy​dμ(x)=−i1​μ(R)=iμ(R).

    If C≠0C \neq 0C=0, then yf(iy)yf\p{iy}yf(iy) would be unbounded, which implies that C=0C = 0C=0. Thus,

    i=lim⁡n→∞yf(iy)=iμ(R)  ⟹  μ(R)=1,i = \lim_{n\to\infty} yf\p{iy} = i\mu\p{\R} \implies \mu\p{\R} = 1,i=n→∞lim​yf(iy)=iμ(R)⟹μ(R)=1,

    so μ(R)\mu\p{\R}μ(R) is a probability measure.
